results.title: The German language series. Part 4
results.creator_credit: University of Wisconsin and Herman J. Engel
results.brief_description: This series allows the student to hear and see native speakers of German conducting a conversation lasting about two minutes. The dialogue is broken down into parts which are repeated four times to allow the student to imitate the pronunciation and intonation of the speaker. Part four presents dialogue on the building of a new house, using basic sounds in complex sentences. In English and German.

results.title: The German language series. Part 1
results.creator_credit: University of Wisconsin and Herman J. Engel
results.brief_description: This series allows the student to hear and see native speakers of German conducting a conversation lasting about two minutes. The dialogue is broken down into parts which are repeated four times to allow the student to imitate the pronunciation and intonation of the speaker. Part one presents dialogue on the arrival in Germany of a friend from America, using simple sentences with present tense. In English and German.

results.title: The Geography of Canada
results.brief_description: Documentary short on Canada’s geographical regions - the Pacific West Coast, the Interior Plains, the Canadian Shield, the St. Lawrence Valley, Appalachian region; and the arctic. Both animated dolls and live footage are used to provide facts on plant and animal life, Canada’s neighbours, climatic conditions, natural resources and wildlife conservation. Scenes of a beaver building a dam.

results.title: The Gentleman in room 6
results.creator_credit: George K. Arthur, Meteor Films and Alexander Hammid
results.brief_description: Short story film about a derelict and forgotten character hiding in a room womewhere in South America. he is confronted by three of his old associates, each of whom provides further clues to his identity which is revealed in the last few seconds of the film.

results.title: The Gentle art of film projection
results.creator_credit: Michael Spencer, ONF | NFB and Donald Peters
results.brief_description: Some pointers on the art of film projection, told through the humorous story of a poor showman who lost his film audience because he didn’t know how to operate a 16mm projector. The moment that George Beesley appears on the scene we know something ridiculous is bound to happen—and it does! This sad sack merrily muddles through the film showing and annoys his audience so thoroughly that they walk out in disgust. An interested spectator then patiently explains the principles of efficient projection, while animated sequences demonstrate the construction of a projector, the preparation in advance of the room to be used for the showing, and the correct placement of screen and loudspeaker. Procedures for preventing damage to film and equipment are outlined. Animation by Wolf Koenig.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Spencer, ONF | NFB and Donald Peters

results.title: The Genie from downunder. - Vol. 6.
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, Jeremy Swan and Esben Storm
results.brief_description: In “Triple treat”, confusion reigns supreme when Conrad and Otto make two replica’s of Penelope’s magic opal. There’s lots of opal rubbing but little magic as a result! Bruce finally gets the opal back to the cave in “It’s still magic” and is about to free himself when Penelope and Baz accuse him of selfishness. Eventually some sort of compromise is reached and Bruce finds out about the magic of romance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Children’s Television Foundation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, Jeremy Swan and Esben Storm

results.title: The Genie from downunder. - Vol. 5.
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, Jeremy Swan and Esben Storm
results.brief_description: In a ‘Tale of two cities’, Conrad works out that Bruce and Baz are genies and tries to learn more about their secret powers. In ‘School daze’ Penelope wishes herself back in England to avoid having to go to school in Australia and finds that she has to sit a “catch up” exam at her school when she returns.
